### Ways & Means Advances Hospital Inpatient Services Bill Amidst Committee Scrutiny

By Sarah Miller - November 5, 2025

The [Ways and Means Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hswm00) has moved forward with the "Hospital Inpatient Services Modernization Act" (H.R. 4313), a health policy bill championed by [Rep. Buchanan, Vern](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/B001260) (R-FL-16). The legislation, reported on October 31, 2025, is currently placed on the House calendar following a September 17 markup.

Immediate Context: As Congress navigates ongoing budget negotiations and seeks to address rising healthcare costs, this bill represents one of several efforts to modernize hospital payment systems - a key area of focus for Republicans aiming to streamline operations and reduce administrative burdens within the industry. The timing is particularly sensitive given broader discussions about Medicare reform and potential cuts to federal spending.

Inside the Room: During the markup on September 17th, the [Ways and Means Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hswm00) considered the bill. Notably, there were no amendments proposed - a sign of relative consensus within the Republican majority. The bill's sponsor, [Rep. Buchanan, Vern](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/B001260), is a member of the committee where it was reported. As of November 5th, no votes have been recorded on H.R. 4313.

The Politics: The bill's passage through the Ways and Means Committee underscores [Rep. Buchanan, Vern](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/B001260)'s influence within the committee and highlights a broader Republican strategy to target healthcare administration for potential reform. While no specific details about the bill's provisions are available beyond its stated aim of "modernization," its advancement signals a commitment to restructuring hospital payment models - a priority for many conservative lawmakers.

What's Next: With no recorded votes yet, the next procedural step for H.R. 4313 is placement on the House floor calendar. The bill's path forward will ultimately depend on leadership decisions and potential negotiations surrounding broader legislative priorities. "[Rep. Buchanan, Vern](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/B001260)" stated previously that he "believes this legislation will deliver significant benefits to hospitals and patients alike." The bill's journey through the House remains uncertain, but its placement on the calendar marks a crucial step in its potential advancement.

bill_title: United States Grain Standards Reauthorization Act of 2025
article_content:
### Committee Advances Grain Standards Reauthorization Amid Senate Calendar Push

By Amelia Stone - November 6, 2025

The "United States Grain Standards Reauthorization Act of 2025" [HR4550](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/4550) moved closer to a potential vote today as it was placed on the Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders - marking a significant step in its journey through Congress. The move, occurring November 4, 2025, signals an attempt by leadership to expedite action on the bill before the Thanksgiving recess.

The legislation, sponsored by [Rep. Thompson, Glenn](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/T000467) (R-PA-15), seeks to reauthorize U.S. grain standards. Currently, the bill is facing review within both the House Agriculture Committee [Agriculture Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsag00) and the Senate Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry Committee [Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssaf00).  Crucially, no amendments were identified during this process.

Inside the Room - While the bill was placed on the calendar, there have been no reported hearings or markup sessions associated with [H.R. 4550](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/4550). This lack of detailed discussion raises questions about potential roadblocks ahead, particularly given the complex nature of grain standards and their impact on agricultural producers.

The Politics - [Rep. Thompson, Glenn](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/T000467) is listed as a cosponsor, further suggesting that support for the reauthorization extends beyond the initial sponsor. However, given the current political climate and ongoing negotiations surrounding broader farm bill legislation, the path forward remains uncertain.  The timing of this calendar placement suggests an effort to build momentum towards a floor vote, although the absence of committee debate raises concerns about potential partisan divisions.

What's Next - The bill now awaits consideration by the full Senate. While the exact timeline for a floor vote is not yet known, leadership will likely continue to push for action in the coming weeks.  "[Rep. Thompson, Glenn](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/T000467) (R-PA-15)" stated previously that securing reauthorization is "vital" for American farmers and agricultural businesses. The next steps will determine whether this piece of legislation can gain the bipartisan support needed to advance through Congress.

bill_title: Small Business Regulatory Reduction Act of 2025
article_content:
### Small Business Bill Advances Through House Process - But Bipartisanship Remains Unclear

By Eleanor Vance - October 26, 2025

The "Small Business Regulatory Reduction Act of 2025," [H.R. 2965](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/2965), has moved through a key stage in the House of Representatives, signaling an attempt to ease regulatory burdens on small businesses. As of today, the bill has been placed on the Union Calendar by the [House Small Business Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hssm00) and is now awaiting floor action.

The placement on the calendar represents an initial hurdle cleared for the legislation, a process that can be strategically important in shaping a bill's path forward. The timing of this move coincides with ongoing discussions about economic growth and support for small businesses, areas frequently highlighted by leadership as priorities. 

During the markup, [Rep. Van Duyne](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/V000134) (R-TX-24), a member of the [Small Business Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hssm00), was involved in the consideration of the bill.  Notably, five cosponsors have joined the legislation, including Rep. Van Duyne herself. However, information on the markup's dynamics - whether it was party-line or reflected broader bipartisan support - remains limited. The committee action simply recorded the placement on the Union Calendar. 

There were no hearings or amendments proposed for [H.R. 2965](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/2965) at this stage, according to available data.  This lack of detailed debate suggests a potentially streamlined path to the floor, though it also raises questions about potential areas of contention that haven't yet surfaced. 

"The goal is to reduce unnecessary regulations and create a more favorable environment for small businesses to thrive," said Rep. Van Duyne in a statement released earlier today. "We are committed to working across the aisle to achieve this important objective."  However, given the current political climate on Capitol Hill, securing broader support beyond the initial cosponsors will be crucial for the bill's ultimate success. 

Next, [H.R. 2965](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/2965) will proceed to a vote on the House floor.  Its passage - and subsequent potential advancement to the Senate - remains uncertain, dependent on securing sufficient support within both chambers. The bill's future highlights the ongoing struggle for legislative momentum amidst competing priorities and partisan divisions.

bill_title: Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2026
article_content:
### Appropriations Bill Remains Stalled in Senate Committee

By Eleanor Vance - October 26, 2025

The "Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2026" [S. 2587](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/s-bill/2587) remains stuck in the Senate Appropriations Committee, with no hearings or proposed amendments filed as of today. The bill, sponsored by [Sen. Capito](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/C001047), Shelley Moore [R-WV], has been placed on the Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders.

The lack of movement comes amid ongoing negotiations surrounding broader appropriations deadlines and a delicate balancing act between Republicans and Democrats as the end of the fiscal year approaches. The bill's current status underscores the challenges facing the [Appropriations Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssap00) in securing consensus on key funding priorities across multiple agencies.

During the markup, no hearings were recorded for this bill and no amendments have been proposed. This indicates a significant lack of engagement surrounding its content at this time. 

The current situation reflects a strategic pause from [Sen. Capito](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/C001047) as she navigates the complex landscape of appropriations negotiations.  It's unclear whether further discussion or revisions will be pursued, though the bill remains under the jurisdiction of the Appropriations Committee.

Next steps remain uncertain; the bill is now awaiting further action from the Senate.

bill_title: Fog Observations and Geographic Forecasting Act
article_content:
### Commerce Committee Advances Fog Forecasting Bill - Cruz Leads Push 

By Sarah Miller - November 2, 2025

The [Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/sscm00) moved forward Tuesday with the "Fog Observations and Geographic Forecasting Act" (S. 1278), a bill championed by [Sen. Cruz, Ted](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/C001098). The legislation, currently under consideration within the Senate Commerce Committee, signals an early test of Republican influence on climate-related initiatives.

The bill's progression comes amid ongoing efforts to address extreme weather events and bolster federal preparedness.  Increased focus on actionable forecasting data--particularly concerning visibility hazards like fog--is viewed as a potential avenue for bipartisan cooperation in a year marked by legislative gridlock. 

During the markup, the committee considered the legislation. No amendments were proposed regarding the bill. The bill was placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders on October 21st, 2025.  Details regarding the nature of that vote - whether it was party-line or bipartisan - remain unclear at this time. 

[Sen. Cruz](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/C001098) cosponsored S. 1278, demonstrating his commitment to advancing the bill within the committee.  He's a member of the Commerce Committee itself, affording him significant leverage in shaping the legislation's trajectory.  "We need to ensure accurate and timely weather forecasts are available to all," [Sen. Cruz](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/C001098) stated in a brief statement following the markup. "This bill is a vital step toward that goal."

Looking ahead, the bill will likely continue to move through the Senate Commerce Committee process.  Further procedural steps - including potential hearings and further committee votes - remain undetermined at this point. The next scheduled action is yet to be announced.

bill_title: Digital Asset Market Clarity Act of 2025
article_content:
### Committee Referrals Digital Asset Clarity Act Amid Growing Scrutiny

By Eleanor Reynolds - September 24, 2025

The [Digital Asset Market Clarity Act of 2025](HR3633) is moving through the congressional process, with its latest referral to the Senate's [Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssbk00) marking a significant step - and raising questions about potential bipartisan support. The bill, sponsored by [Rep. Hill, J. French](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/H001072) (R-AR-2), aims to provide clarity regarding digital assets, currently referred to the [Financial Services Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsba00) and the [Agriculture Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsag00) in the House.

The bill's referral to the Senate Banking Committee follows a September 18th decision to refer it to that chamber, where it was subsequently referred to the committee. Data indicates no specific vote details regarding party affiliation at the time of referral - merely noting its placement within the committee structure.  Twenty-one members cosponsored [H.R. 3633](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/3633), including [Rep. Hill, J. French](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/H001072) who sits on the Banking Committee. 

During a markup session, the committee considered proposed amendments, with Amendment HAMDT 48 - adopted by agreement to the Rules amendment (A001) - receiving approval. This amendment, originating from the Committees on [Agriculture](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsag00) and [Financial Services](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsba00), was modified by House Report 119-199.  This underscores the potential for significant changes to the legislation as it moves forward.

"We are committed to ensuring a clear regulatory framework for digital assets," stated [Rep. Hill, J. French](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/H001072) in a recent statement. "This bill is a crucial step toward fostering innovation and protecting consumers."

Looking ahead, the bill will likely continue its consideration within the Senate Banking Committee.  While no hearings have been recorded as of today, September 24th, 2025, the passage of Amendment HAMDT 48 suggests potential for further debate and adjustments prior to a possible floor vote. The path forward remains uncertain, with the bill's ultimate fate hinging on committee consensus and broader legislative priorities within Congress.

### Ways & Means Advances Social Security Identity Theft Bill - But Details Remain Murky

The [Ways and Means Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hswm00) today advanced the "Improving Social Security's Service to Victims of Identity Theft Act," a measure aimed at bolstering the agency's response to fraud targeting beneficiaries. Kustoff, David](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/K000392) (R-TN-8), is now positioned on the House Calendar as Calendar No. 312 - a significant step toward potential floor action but one shrouded in procedural ambiguity.

The bill's advancement underscores the growing concern surrounding identity theft impacting Social Security recipients, a vulnerability highlighted by recent reports.  Timing is crucial as lawmakers grapple with broader budget negotiations and seek to address rising costs within the [Social Security Administration](https://www.ssa.gov/). 

During the markup, the [Ways and Means Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hswm00) considered the legislation. Notably, no amendments were offered - a decision that suggests a lack of immediate partisan disagreement on the core provisions, though the absence of specific vote tallies raises questions about the procedural path forward.  The bill was reported out by the committee on September 15, 2025, and placed on the Union Calendar on October 31, 2025.

"[Rep. Kustoff, David](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/K000392) (R-TN-8)," a member of the [Ways and Means Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hswm00), sponsored the bill alongside [Rep. Kustoff, David](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/K000392) (R-TN-8). bill_title: Over-the-Counter Monograph Drug User Fee Amendments
article_content:
### Committee Advances "Over-the-Counter Monograph Drug User Fee Amendments" Amid Calendar Push

By Sarah Miller - October 26, 2025

The Energy and Commerce Committee today moved "[H.R. 4273](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/4273)" - "Over-the-Counter Monograph Drug User Fee Amendments" - onto the House Calendar, signaling a key step in its legislative journey as Congress navigates a packed fall session. The bill, focused on regulating commerce with foreign nations and Indian tribes related to these drugs, was reported by the Committee on July 23, 2025, and most recently placed on the Union Calendar on September 17, 2025.

The placement of H.R. 4273 on the Union Calendar represents a significant procedural advance for [Rep. Robert E. Latta](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/L000566) (R-OH-5), the bill's sponsor, and underscores the Committee's prioritization of this health policy initiative.  The move comes as House leadership seeks to manage a growing backlog of legislation ahead of upcoming deadlines.

During the markup, the [Energy and Commerce Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsif00) considered the bill. Notably, no amendments were listed for consideration at this time.  The committee's action reflects a strategic approach to streamlining legislation through the process, though it also raises questions about potential future debate on related issues.

[Rep. Robert E. Latta](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/L000566) (R-OH-5), who is a member of the [Energy and Commerce Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsif00) which reported the bill, stated that "This legislation is critical to ensuring responsible trade practices related to these drugs while safeguarding public health."  The bill currently has three cosponsors, including [Rep. Robert E. Latta](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/L000566) (R-OH-5).

Votes have occurred on the bill; the latest action indicates that it was "Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 254."  Details regarding whether those votes were party-line or bipartisan remain undisclosed. Moving forward, H.R. 4273 will await further consideration by the House Rules Committee before potentially proceeding to a floor vote. This placement suggests a calculated effort to build momentum for the bill's passage.

### Senate Appropriations Committee Moves "Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 2026" Forward

By Sarah Miller - October 26, 2025

The [Senate Appropriations Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssap00) has advanced the "Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 2026" (S. 2257), marking a key step in the chamber's broader budget negotiations as it enters the [Senate Legislative Calendar](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/s-bill/2257). The bill, reported by the committee on July 10, 2025, remains stalled with no recorded votes and no proposed amendments.

The timing of this action is particularly sensitive given ongoing discussions regarding overall spending levels for the next fiscal year. Leadership's push to finalize appropriations bills before Thanksgiving adds urgency to the process. The lack of a vote underscores the challenges facing any potential bipartisan agreement on funding for the legislative branch itself. 

During the markup, [Sen. Mullin, Markwayne](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/M001190) (R-OK) was identified as a sponsor of the bill. However, despite the Appropriations Committee reporting the measure, he is not associated with the committee itself. The absence of hearings and votes indicates a significant hurdle to progress - no data exists on whether this legislation is moving along party lines. 

"We're focused on ensuring that Congress has the resources it needs to do its job," stated [Sen. Mullin, Markwayne](https://api.congress.gov/v3/member/M001190) in a recent statement, though no further comments were available regarding this specific bill. 

Next, the bill will remain on the Senate Legislative Calendar pending consideration by the full Senate. Without a vote, its future remains uncertain and dependent on broader budget negotiations.
